Graphical abstract This review discusses the development, synthesis methods, crystal structure characteristics, precise preparation strategies, and diverse applications of Prussian blue and its analogues. Prussian blue/Prussian blue analogues (PB/PBAs) are widely used in electrochemistry and materials science fields, such as electrochemical energy storage, catalysis, water purification, and electromagnetic wave absorption, owing to their 3D open-framework structure, tunable composition, and large specific surface area. However, the co-precipitation method, which is most suitable for large-scale production of PB/PBAs, often leads to the formation of numerous crystal defects and severe lattice distortion, which significantly affects the structural stability of PB/PBAs. To obtain high-crystallinity PB/PBAs with targeted properties, precise synthesis considering various detailed conditions is especially needed. Herein, this review comprehensively summarizes the fundamental structure composition, key factors in synthesis, and applications in the electrochemistry of PB/PBAs. Unlike previous reports, this review elucidates the relationship between the physicochemical properties of PB/PBAs and their structural composition, with a particular focus on revealing the mechanisms and significance of specific preparation methods during the synthesis process, including reactant concentration, chelating agent, aging, atmosphere, temperature, and drying conditions, for achieving the precise fabrication of PB/PBAs nanomaterials. As PB/PBAs gradually become materials for multidimensional applications, we urge greater attention to the unique properties of PB/PBAs that are sustained by high crystallinity and stable crystal structures. This will effectively ensure the maximization of their advantages in practical applications. Keywords Prussian blue Prussian blue analogue Inorganic synthesis Electrochemical energy storage Nanomaterial 1 Introduction Prussian blue/Prussian blue analogues (PB/PBAs) are compounds with specific structures that belong to the ferricyanides in the field of coordination chemistry [1–4]. Due to their 3D open-framework structure, ease of preparation, and low cost, they have concentrated tremendous research interest in the fields of electrochemistry and materials science [5–7]. PB/PBAs are the old type of materials though it is still actively applied in our modern life. Fig. 1 briefly showcases the development history of PB/PBAs. In 1704, Johann Jacob Diesbach, a color manufacturer in Berlin, accidentally discovered PB, a deep blue compound, through the co-precipitation method [8,9]. Since then, PB has been widely applied in the dye industry and gradually became one of the most important pigments in the art world [10,11]. In the early 19th century, scientists began to conduct in-depth studies on the chemical composition and structure of PB. They discovered that PB is recognized as a compound with a complex three-dimensional network structure, containing iron and cyanide groups, with the chemical formula F e 4 [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 3 [8,12]. Subsequent studies have revealed that due to the excellent redox properties of the iron cyanide complex, PB can undergo reversible electron transfer between Fe2+ and Fe3+, enabling it to serve as an effective electron transfer mediator in electrochemical reactions [13–16]. During the 20th century, it was revealed that the metal center of PB could be replaced by other metal ions (Co, Ni, Mn, etc.), leading to the development of various PBAs, which can be represented by the general formula A x T [ M ( C N ) 6 ] · n H 2 O [17–19]. In the 21st century, PB/PBAs have attracted increasing attention in the field of electrochemistry due to their unique structure and properties, with applications in batteries [20–23], supercapacitors [24–26], electrocatalysis [27–30], and water treatment [31–33], among others. Moreover, PB/PBAs derivatives are widely used in high-tech fields, such as energy storage [21,34,35], environmental remediation [36–39], and catalysis [40–42]. Hitherto, PB/PBAs have been becoming a type of star material in our industrial society. The scalable synthesis of high-crystallinity PB/PBAs is the key to successful application. However, although the universal co-precipitation method exhibits merits of facile operation and low cost, the obtained PB/PBAs materials are prone to generate structure issues, e.g., vacancies, crystal aggregation, and particle inhomogeneity, owing to complicated details that need meticulous regulation in the period of synthesis [43–47]. Alternatively, some new synthesis methods such as hydrothermal and electrochemical deposition have been developed to produce PB/PBAs with higher crystallinity and stability, aiming to enhance their electrochemical performance and application effectiveness [48,49]. While continuous efforts to improve synthesis techniques have resulted in better quality and stability, these methods are hard to apply to large-scale production of PB/PBAs [50–52]. So far, many researchers are dedicated to optimizing traditional co-precipitation methods by adjusting synthesis factors such as reactant concentrations and the use of chelating agents to prepare PB/PBAs nanomaterials with fewer vacancies [53–55]. Unfortunately, previous studies have primarily focused on the impact of one or two synthesis factors on the structural quality of PB/PBAs, failing to reveal the interrelationships among all synthesis factors. In addition, although some reviews on PB/PBAs have highlighted the harmful effects of low-quality PB/PBAs and proposed solutions, a comprehensive regulation strategy and corresponding rationale still remain unclear [9,18,56–58]. Therefore, it still faces significant challenges for the precise synthesis of PB/PBAs nanomaterials for various applications. Herein, this review aims to offer a holistic snapshot of the advancement of PB/PBAs that correlates their structural composition with their physicochemical properties. The physicochemical properties of PB/PBAs are closely related to five major components in their structure, i.e., alkali metal, transition metal coordinated with carbon, transition metal coordinated with nitrogen, structural water, and structural vacancies [59–61]. More importantly, we hope to pinpoint the essential role played by synthesis factors that enable low-cost and large-scale production in the high crystallinity and low-defect PB/PBAs crystal structures. A comprehensive summary of the synthesis factors involved in the co-precipitation method, along with the elucidation of the corresponding mechanisms of action of different factors in the preparation of high-crystallinity PB/PBAs, has been reported for the first time. On top of that, after clarifying the relationship between the composition and physicochemical properties of PB/PBAs, the precise preparation of PB/PBAs can be achieved through the synergistic regulation of synthesis factors, such as adjustable particle size, compositional elements, and lattice parameters. This unprecedented discovery will open up new possibilities for PB/PBAs. 2 Synthesis method for PB/PBAs Currently, many methods have been reported to synthesize PB/PBAs materials, which can be classified into (1) co-precipitation, (2) single source method, (3) electrochemical deposition, and (4) ball milling method. Products prepared by different approaches feature various characteristics in crystallinity, cost, safety, and scalability (Fig. 2 ). Thus, suitable synthesis methods should be selected based on the requirement of target materials. 2.1 Co-precipitation method The co-precipitation method is the most common and classical approach for PB/PBAs synthesis [62,63]. Specifically, it involves mixing solutions containing transition metal ions and ferrocyanide or ferricyanide ligands, leading to a rapid reaction of these ions to generate solid precipitates of PBAs [64]. For example, Manganese Hexacyanoferrate (MnHCF) can be synthesized using the co-precipitation method from M n S O 4 solution and K 4 F e ( C N ) 6 solution [65]. This synthesis method is characterized by its low cost, simplicity of operation, and environmental friendliness. However, the morphology and crystallinity of the materials obtained from co-precipitation reactions are often difficult to control [66,67]. Therefore, the microscopic morphology of PB/PBAs can be adjusted by varying the experimental conditions, which will be elaborated upon in subsequent sections. 2.2 Single source hydrothermal method PB/PBAs can be synthesized under specific conditions through the decomposition and reorganization of a single-source cyanide framework. During the hydrothermal process, [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - slowly decomposes and releases Fe3+ ions under acid solutions, which then reacts with the remaining [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - to form PB [15,68]. To prepare PB powder, Wang et al. added an appropriate amount of hydrochloric acid solution to a solution of N a 4 F e ( C N ) 6 , then transferred the mixture to a Teflon container and hydrothermally treated at 65 °C for 24 h [69]. Similarly, [ C o ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - can decompose and resynthesize PBAs under acidic hydrothermal conditions [70,71]. It is important to note that the cyanide groups formed from transition metals and cyanide ions (such as [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - and [ C o ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - ) serve as the sole precursors in this synthesis method, which allows for the synthesis of PB materials with fewer defects and higher crystallinity. However, the single-source hydrothermal method can only synthesize PB/PBAs containing a single transition metal. In addition, the generation of toxic cyanides during the heat treatment process and the low yield of PB/PBAs from the implemented reactor of Teflon-lined autoclave severely hinder their application in neither research nor practical production [43]. 2.3 Electrochemical deposition Electrochemical synthesis of PB/PBAs involves the deposition of PB/PBAs films on the substrate surface through electrolytic reactions, which is a commonly-used method for the preparation of membranes or electrode materials [72]. In an electrolytic cell, a voltage is applied to the ionic solution, causing cations and anions to migrate toward the electrodes, where they undergo redox reactions accompanied by charge transfer to generate PB/PBAs [73,74]. He et al. directly grew K 2 Zn 3 [ Fe ( CN ) 6 ] 2 · 9 H 2 O on carbon cloth via an electrodeposition method to serve as a binder-free self-supporting membrane electrode for aqueous rechargeable sodium-ion batteries, significantly enhancing the ion diffusion rate and conductivity [75]. This method allows the effective control of the thickness and uniformity of the PBAs layers, making it suitable for the fabrication of electrochemical devices. However, it requires highly complex equipment and procedures, which results in significant costs for large-scale production [40]. 2.4 Solid-phase ball milling method The ball milling method is a solid-state reaction technique that utilizes mechanical energy to facilitate the reaction process. In this method, metal ion precursors are mixed with cyanide ligands as solid reactants to react in the absence of solvents under the aid of mechanical energy of the friction and collision between the particles, achieving the preparation of PB/PBAs products [76,77]. Peng et al. synthesized highly crystalline N a 1.66 M n [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 1.00 with low defects and moisture content using a ball milling solid-state method, which demonstrated excellent discharge capacity and rate performance in sodium-ion batteries at temperatures ranging from 10 to 50 °C [78]. This method is not only efficient and environmentally friendly but also suitable for large-scale synthesis; however, the uniformity of the products may be limited [79]. Overall, from different perspectives of pursuit, these synthesis methods have their respective advantages and disadvantages. Notably, the co-precipitation method stands out with balanced and prominent advantages across various parameters, making it suitable for production at different scales. 3 Crystal-structural composition of PB/PBAs The chemical formula of PB and PBAs can be described as F e 4 [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 3 · n H 2 O and A x T [ M ( C N ) 6 ] · n H 2 O , respectively (Fig. 3 ), where A represents alkali metal (Li, Na, K, etc.) and T / M denotes transition metals (T = M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Zn, Cu, V, etc.) [80–82]. Taking PBAs as an example, hexacyanometallate salts exhibit a face-centered cubic structure with the space group Fm3m, with M positioned at the center of the hexacyanometallate [9,83]. Typically, low-spin M transition metal ions coordinate with the carbon in the CN bond, while high-spin T transition metals coordinate with the nitrogen [84]. This difference in spin states is attributed to the greater splitting of the three-dimensional orbitals of M coordinating with C compared to those of T coordinating with N [85,86]. 3.1 Alkali metal Due to the 3D open-framework structure of PB/PBAs, which is suitable for the storage of ions such as lithium, sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium, aluminum, and zinc, they can be utilized as cathode materials for ion batteries [87,88]. Among these, alkali metals are the most commonly studied insertion ions ( A ), located at the center positions of the cubic lattice [50]. The free energy of the ion insertion reaction is influenced by several factors, including the effective ionic radius, types of PB/PBAs, and the effects of the electrolyte and solvent [89]. When copper hexacyanoferrate is used as the insertion host in the organic electrolyte, the reaction potentials for the alkali ions Li+, Na+, and K+ are sequentially 0.5, 0.77, and 0.93 V (vs. standard hydrogen electrode, SHE) [90]. In contrast, when nickel hexacyanoferrate serves as the insertion host in an aqueous electrolyte, the reaction potentials for the same alkali ions are respectively 0.379, 0.583, and 0.721 V (vs. SHE) [91]. It is worth noting that the lattice parameters would shrink during the ion insertion process in PB/PBAs owing to the increase of electron density, leading to the contract and lattice distortion of the hexacyanometallate complexes [92]. Additionally, the number of alkali metal ions directly influences the crystal structure of PB/PBAs; as their quantity increases, the cubic phase tends to transform into a rhombohedral structure [93]. 3.2 Low-spin M transition metal The coordination of C with different transition metals ( M ) results in varying MC bond lengths, which directly affects the lattice parameters and framework size of PBAs, causing a difference in their ionic conductivity [94]. Specifically, replacing a smaller transition metal element with one that has a larger atomic radius will result in an increase in the lattice parameters [95]. Additionally, the transition metal M sites serve as typical redox centers within the PBAs structure, so altering the metal elements coordinated with C leads to different redox reaction potentials. Using the SHE as a reference, the reaction potential ranges for the redox pairs of hexacyanochromate (Cr3+/Cr2+), hexacyanomanganate (Mn3+/Mn2+), and hexacyanoferrate (Fe3+/Fe2+) are approximately −0.9 to −0.5 V, 0–0.4 V, and 0.8–1.1 V, respectively [96]. Consequently, hexacyanoferrate, with its higher redox potential, is more frequently utilized as the cathode material in energy storage batteries. 3.3 High-spin T transition metal The radius of transition metal T ions also influences the lattice parameters and the dimensions of the 3D open-framework channels [97,98]. However, compared to the metal M site, the metal T site offers a greater variety of element options in the pursuit of different practical types of PBAs. When different transition metals are used to replace the T sites, only Zn induces a transformation of the PBAs's nanocubic structure into a cubic octahedral shape, whereas other metal counterparts do not. However, from an electrochemical perspective, significant differences are observed [99,100]. Transition metals at the M site with high ionic potential (the ionic charge/ionic radius) lead to higher redox potentials for the T ions, which is attributed to the more pronounced polarization of the σ bonds and π back-bonding in the cyanide complexes, as well as the lower energy of the t2g orbitals of the M ions [50,96]. Specifically, PBAs can be categorized into two types based on the reactivity of the T metal. (1) Inert PBAs represented by electrochemically inactive transition metals such as Ni, Zn, and Cu, which feature only one pair of redox couples ( M 2 + / M 3 + ) [101,102]. (2) Active PBAs represented by electrochemically active transition metals such as Fe, Co, Mn, and V, which possess two pairs of redox couples ( M 2 + / M 3 + and T 2 + / T 3 + ) [100,103]. Compared to inert PBAs, active PBAs can lead to structural collapse and damage structural stability during the redox process. In general, when PBAs formed from the reaction of transition metal salts ( T 2 + / T 3 + ) and metal cyanide ions ( [ M ( I I ) ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - / [ M ( I I I ) ( C N ) 6 ] 3 - ) include only two types of transition metals, they are referred to as binary PBAs. Similarly, when PBAs contain three, four, or more types of transition metal ions, they are classified as ternary PBAs, quaternary PBAs, and high-entropy PBAs, respectively. Fortunately, if the T site contains multiple different transition metal elements, the PBAs can integrate the physicochemical properties of these elements [104,105]. Therefore, the redox properties, structural stability, and physicochemical properties of PBAs can be tuned by controlling the type and quantity of elements at the T site. 3.4 Structural water Water in the structure of PB/PBAs exists in three forms, i.e., adsorbed water, zeolitic water, and coordinated water [18,39,106]. Adsorbed water is retained on the surface of the PB/PBAs, while zeolitic water is embedded within the structural cavities of the PB/PBAs, competing for positions with alkali metal ions ( A ) [107,108]. Coordinated water forms bonds with the T metal ions situated in vacancies [109–111]. Among the water molecules located in these different positions, adsorbed water and zeolitic water are weakly bound to the PB/PBAs structure and can be easily removed, whereas coordinated water, which is bonded to the T transition metal ions, is more difficult to eliminate [112,113]. The electronegativity of the oxygen in water molecules can shield the positive charge of the transition metal ions [50]. However, structural water can undergo reactions at high potentials, and the excessive electrolysis of water molecules may lead to the collapse of the PB/PBAs structure, hindering the application of PB/PBAs in various fields [102]. Generally, heat treatment can remove the water molecules. It is worth noting that water molecules play a crucial role in supporting the framework structure of PB/PBAs due to that the decrease of zeolitic water can induce phase transitions in the PB/PBAs structure and the coordination water can compensate for defects to reinforce structural bonding [114]. Merely reducing the water content in the PB/PBAs structure to stabilize electrochemical properties can lead to structural instability. Therefore, a synergistic approach involving the doping of inert T metal ions may help maintain structural stability by water content. 3.5 Structural vacancies In the period of synthesis for PB/PBAs, the presence of a water-rich environment can lead to the occupation of a significant number of M ( C N ) 6 sites by water, resulting in the formation of structural vacancies (Fig. 4 ) [67]. These vacancies have numerous negative effects on the electrochemical performance of PB/PBAs [15,115,116]. (1) The absence of M ( C N ) 6 results in defects of positive charge, which severely impact the discharge specific capacity of PB/PBAs commonly used as electrode materials. (2) The competitive mechanism between coordinated water and alkali metal ions due to defect formation leads to a reduction in the available sites for ion insertion and hinders the transport of ions within the PB/PBAs lattice. (3) The water molecules within the lattice may migrate into organic solutions, causing contamination, and could also undergo electrochemical decomposition, leading to the destruction of the crystal structure. (4) The random distribution of defects disrupts the periodicity of the crystal structure, resulting in compromised structural stability of PB/PBAs in various applications. To suppress the formation of internal defects in PBAs, the key strategy is to reduce the reaction rate, increase the concentration of alkali metal ions, regulate the reaction environment, and modulate ion doping in the synthesis process. The following section will delve into a comprehensive discussion of the various factors that exert an impact on the regulation of PB/PBAs structures for co-precipitation synthesis approach. 4 Fine regulation for synthesizing high-crystallinity PB/PBAs Among various synthesis methods for PB/PBAs, the co-precipitation method is the most convenient, cost-effective, and commonly used [117]. However, its structural defects are particularly pronounced in aqueous environments, significantly limiting its application performance. Therefore, a fine regulation for the synthesis details is quite essential to promote the quality of PB/PBAs products. In this section, we comprehensively discuss the modification methods for different influence factors during the co-precipitation preparation, including reactant concentration, chelating agent, feed condition, aging time, reaction temperature, reaction atmosphere, and drying condition ( Fig. 5 ). Meanwhile, the fundamental behind these modulations is also elucidated. This could provide a systematical reference and aid researchers in synthesizing directed high-crystallinity PB/PBAs products. 4.1 Reactant concentration The concentration of reactants is an indispensable factor in the synthesis of materials. Typically, the co-precipitation for PB/PBAs requires two major types of reactants, i.e., transition metal salts and hexacyanometallate salts [118,119]. What is often overlooked is that the concentrations of these reactants significantly impact the lattice structure of the PB/PBAs. Research on the single-source hydrothermal method has shown that the concentration of alkali metal precursor solutions positively correlates with the CN groups within PB/PBAs, which indicates that high concentrations of alkali metal ions promote the formation of high-defect PB/PBAs due to competitive interaction with H2O [120]. This conclusion is also applicable to the co-precipitation synthesis method. Excess hexacyanometallate salts containing alkali metal ions ( mol A mol T > 1 ) are required to synthesize high-quality PB/PBAs [121]. Moreover, the increase in total reactant concentration would result in more vacancies and structural water due to the balance between crystal nucleation and growth. For instance, Li et al. prepared K 1.169 N a 0.002 M n [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.908 · 0.903 H 2 O through three molar ratios ( mol A mol T = 0.75 0.25 , 1.5 0.5 , 3 1 ) that with an increase in the total concentration of reactants, which demonstrated the content of M ( C N ) 6 vacancies and coordinated water increases when prepared at high-concentration condition [122]. Additionally, high reactant concentration usually gives rise to forming more nuclei, leading to smaller PB/PBAs nanocrystal sizes [119,121]. Therefore, selecting the appropriate reactant concentration is fundamental to the preparation of high-quality PB/PBAs. 4.2 Chelating agent During the synthesis of PB/PBAs, rapid crystallization and growth often result in a significant number of M ( C N ) 6 vacancies within the structure [123]. These vacancies severely disrupt the periodic lattice arrangement, leading to deteriorated electrochemical performance. To enhance the crystallinity of the material, the utilization of chelating agents has become a simple and efficient approach. In conventional co-precipitation synthesis processes, transition metal ions ( T 2 + / T 3 + ) and metal cyanide ions ( [ M ( I I ) ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - / [ M ( I I I ) ( C N ) 6 ] 3 - ) exist freely without any constraints, causing rapid nucleation and growth of the crystal. It readily results in numerous defects within the PB/PBAs structure and significant aggregation of crystals (Fig. 6 ) [124,125]. Therefore, chelating agents are widely used because they can preferentially capture T 2 + to form complexes. Subsequently, T 2 + is gradually released and combines with the free [ M ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - to form initial nuclei. Han et al. utilized trisodium citrate as a chelating agent to reduce the release rate of Ni ions, thereby synthesizing low-defect hexacyanoferrate nickel hexacyanoferrate nanocrystals [125]. In addition to citrate salts, commonly used chelating agents include ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid salt and triethanolamine. A potential limitation is that the coordination ability varies significantly between different chelating agents and transition metals. Therefore, inappropriate use of chelating agents may still lead to the presence of defects. Generally, sodium citrate is considered a strong chelating agent, while disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetate and triethanolamine are regarded as mild chelating agents. When synthesizing PB/PBAs using a single transition metal ion, mild chelating agents can be used to suppress the structure defects. However, when synthesizing multi-metal PB/PBAs using multiple transition metal ions, even with wild chelating agents, defects may still appear in large quantities within the structure. For instance, the binding ability of disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetate with Cu and Ni ions is significantly greater than that with Mn ions, leading to a higher presence of defects and an imbalance in the elemental ratio. In such cases, the “acid effect” can be applied to weaken the chelation ability of the chelating agent with transition metal ions, achieving relatively uniform reaction rates of different transition metal ions and resulting in highly crystalline multi-metal PBAs. Liu et al. successfully synthesized low-defect multi-metal PBAs by modulating the chelation ability of disodium EDTA with ascorbic acid [126]. The rational use of chelating agents is often underappreciated, and this approach could be more widely promoted. In addition, in the synthesis of PBAs, surfactants and chelating agents may overlap in functionality on controlling the reaction rate), whereas their action mechanism and application aim are different. Chelating agents affect the solubility, migration, and reactivity of metal ions by forming stable complexes or coordination compounds. In contrast, surfactants improve particle dispersion and prevent the aggregation of reactants by adsorbing onto the material's surface or forming protective films, thereby indirectly regulating the reaction rate. As a result, surfactants such as polyvinylpyrrolidone and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide are also commonly used to control the synthesis of low-defect PB/PBAs. 4.3 Feed condition For chelating agents, the reaction rate is slowed down through chemical methods. Additionally, a physical slow feeding of reactant solution can further suppress the rapid nucleation and growth of crystals via a highly-controllable way. In the traditional co-precipitation method, salts containing T 2 + and [ M ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - are prepared as solutions A and B, respectively, and solution A is then added dropwise to solution B [127]. This process involves a critical factor of feeding rate. Specifically, an excess feeding rate will lead to that the reaction becomes excessively vigorous, causing uneven nucleation and crystal growth [37,128]. In addition, the addition of solution A to solution B creates a significant concentration gradient of the reactants, which severely limits the uniformity of the reaction between the reactants. Therefore, to ensure a more favorable crystal growth environment, the concentration gradient of the reactants can be avoided by adding solutions A and B to deionized water (C) at the same rate [38]. Wang et al. successfully synthesized high-performance N a 1.56 F e [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.90 · 2.42 H 2 O cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries by using a Y-tube-assisted coprecipitation method and controlling the feed flow rate to avoid concentration differences of the reactants during the feeding process [59]. The choice of solvent is also an important factor in regulating PB/PBAs. Compared to water, low-polarity organic solvents such as ethanol can effectively control the reaction uniformity and the particle size of the product. In fact, mixed solvents containing water and organic liquid are often used in practical synthesis process. Gu et al. successfully synthesized 5 nm ultra-small Prussian blue nanoparticles using a mixed ethanol/water solvent with a volume ratio of 3:1, which were employed as multifunctional high-performance biomedical agents [129]. Therefore, controlling the solvent and feeding method of the reactants can effectively regulate the reaction rate and control the particle size of PB/PBAs. 4.4 Aging time After the feeding of reactants containing chelating agents, the strong interactions between the chelating agents and transition metal ion complexes lead to that the transition metal ions can only slowly release from the chelating agent’s coordination sphere. Therefore, the subsequent crystal formation process requires rigorous control of the aging time to ensure proper nucleation and growth of the crystals. Specifically, a too-short aging time will prevent the PB/PBAs crystals from fully crystallizing, resulting in smaller particles, while an excessively long aging time may lead to overgrowth of the crystals, causing aggregation [122]. Hou et al. systematically studied the effect of aging time on the preparation of high-quality potassium manganese hexacyanoferrate using sodium citrate as a chelating agent by designing three aging time groups of 12, 24, and 48 h. The results indicated that when the aging time was 24 h, the sample exhibited the optimal microstructure and electrochemical performance [122]. Thus, controlling an appropriate aging time can reduce the water content within the crystal structure, which also implies a lower proportion of vacancies. This is crucial for the synthesis of high-crystallinity PB/PBA crystals with desired particle size. Unfortunately, the release rate of different transition metal ions varies under different coordination conditions, and the 24-h aging time may not be universally applicable. Further research in this direction is still needed. 4.5 Reaction temperature The control of reaction temperature is typically coupled with the use of chelating agents. In the absence of chelating agents, from a thermodynamic perspective, the reaction temperature directly influences the reaction kinetics. Lower temperatures are required to slow down the reaction rate and synthesize PB/PBAs with high crystallinity [130,131]. For instance, Peng et al. utilized a reaction temperature of −10 °C to prepare N a 1.58 F e [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.87 · 2.38 H 2 O energy storage materials with low defect concentrations [132]. Although molecular dynamics increase with temperature under the condition with chelating agents, the effect is far less pronounced compared to the interaction strength between the chelating agents and transition metal ion complexes. The rise in temperature leads to a significant decrease in the Gibbs free energy of the chelating agent-transition metal ion complex, indicating that the stability of the complex is enhanced at higher temperatures [133]. This can further decrease the reaction rate, promoting the formation of high-crystallinity PB/PBAs. It is worth noting that, regardless of the presence of chelating agents, the size of PB/PBAs nanoparticles increases with temperature rise [66,134]. Therefore, the control of reaction temperature should be combined with the use of chelating agents and the binding ability of the chelating agents to different transition metal ions, rather than arbitrarily setting a specific reaction temperature to regulate the reaction rate. 4.6 Reaction atmosphere The reaction atmosphere is generally classified into air and inert gas. In previous studies, N a x F e [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] y was found that the presence of oxygen in the air inevitably leads to the oxidation of PBAs during the reaction and washing processes [14]. In contrast, the use of inert gas (e.g., N2, and Ar) effectively suppresses the oxidation of F e 2 + / [ F e I I ( C N ) 6 ] 4 - to F e 3 + / [ F e I I I ( C N ) 6 ] 3 - , resulting in a lower average oxidation state of Fe and a higher Na content, which is advantageous for energy storage materials. As discussed in the section on alkaline ions, high concentrations of Na+ also lead to the distortion of the coordination environment of the transition metals and phase transitions in the PB/PBAs structure [135,136]. Therefore, the regulation of the reaction atmosphere primarily serves to adjust the proportion of transition metal oxidation states and the alkali metal content within PB/PBAs. This is crucial for the use of PB/PBAs in energy storage electrodes, but is not a major factor in other fields. 4.7 Drying condition The section on structural water has preliminarily outlined the effects of water molecules (adsorbed water, zeolitic water, and coordinated water) and their varying degrees of difficulty in removal. In addition to controlling reaction conditions, thermal treatment is the most convenient method for removing water from the synthesized samples [137]. In the PB structure, the content of adsorbed water and zeolitic water are approximately 10 wt%, and their removal temperature is usually at about 130 °C, while the content and removal temperature of coordinated water are approximately 1.5 wt% and 180 °C (values may vary depending on different PBAs and synthesis methods), respectively [20]. A series of temperature-dependent dynamic detection techniques (such as TG-MS, in-situ XRD, and in-situ Raman) can be employed to determine the optimal drying conditions for different types of PBAs. During the removal of adsorbed water and zeolitic water, the PBAs structure is almost unchanged. However, during the removal of coordinated water, XRD characteristic peaks may merge, and crystal plane shifts may be observed [20,113]. This is primarily attributed to that the coordinated water within the PBAs structure substitutes metal-cyanide ions to maintain the stability of the crystal lattice. Therefore, fundamentally reducing the formation of vacancies through the regulation of reaction conditions can significantly decrease the content of coordinated water. Subsequently, drying conditions can be applied to remove adsorbed water and zeolitic water, thereby minimizing the impact of water molecules on the products. In short, the overall regulation can be summarized into three types as shown in Fig. 7 , i.e., control of lattice parameters, nucleation rate, and growth rate. As the quality of PB/PBAs products is determined by many factors, synergistic regulation is required during actual operations. However, precise preparation through synergistic regulation of multiple factors remains quite challenging owing to the specificity of optimal conditions for different materials. For example, the synthesis factors suitable for high-crystallinity manganese hexacyanoferrate may not be applicable to nickel hexacyanoferrate. Therefore, understanding the regulation principles of different synthesis factors is crucial for preparing high-crystallinity PB/PBAs materials with the desired characteristics. This not only benefits the efficient performance of PB/PBAs in different fields, but also provides a better structural foundation for derivatives of PB/PBAs, such as PBAs/carbon complexes [55,138], derivatives [21,54,60,139], and hollow nanomaterials [140,141], which could be used for wide applications. 5 PB/PBAs applications With the development of science and industrial, PB/PBAs and their derivatives are widely used in electrochemistry, medicine, environmental science and other fields. In this section, we will introduce the applications of PB/PBAs in various fields and their mechanisms of action (Fig. 8 ). 5.1 Electrochemical energy storage As electrode material used in electrochemical energy storage systems, PB/PBAs store and supply energy via de-/intercalation of ions in their structure. Different types of PBAs possess varying numbers of redox pairs. The intercalation and deintercalation of ions within the inert PBAs during the discharge and charge processes of the battery lead to redox reactions involving the M metal [142]. When active PBAs are employed as cathode materials, both M and T metals undergo redox reactions, facilitating a two-electron transfer [85]. The charge and discharge process can be embodied by the following reaction equation. (1) A 2 T I I M I I ( C N ) 6 ↔ A T I I M I I I ( C N ) 6 + A + + e - (2) A 2 T I I M I I ( C N ) 6 ↔ T I I I M I I I ( C N ) 6 + 2 A + + 2 e - Furthermore, PB/PBAs with low-defect and suitable particle sizes not only exhibit excellent compatibility in both organic and aqueous environments but also possess an ideal three-dimensional open-framework structure capable of accommodating large hydrated ions, which makes them suitable for storing both monovalent (Li+, Na+, K+, NH4 +, H+) and multivalent (Zn2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Al3+, etc.) ions. Here we introduce the representative studies on the application of PB/PBAs for metal ion batteries in organic and aqueous electrolyte systems. 5.1.1 Organic electrolyte batteries PB/PBAs are able to operate in high-voltage conditions with excellent structure stability, making them suitable for achieving high energy density in batteries with organic electrolytes. Consequently, PB/PBAs are widely applied in organic energy storage systems, such as the most representative alkali metal-ion batteries. For example, He and co-workers utilized L i 1.05 F e [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.97 · 2.6 H 2 O with nanometer-sized and single-crystalline as the cathode active material in lithium-ion batteries, which demonstrated a reversible capacity of 142 mA h g−1 at 19 mA g−1 [143]. Wessells et al. reported a high-rate, long-life, and low-cost full sodium-ion battery system with N a 1.24 M n [ M n ( C N ) 6 ] 0.81 · 2.1 H 2 O as the anode [144]. Komaba et al. developed an affordable high-voltage organic K-ion full battery with a K 1.75 F e [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.93 · 0.16 H 2 O /graphite configuration [145]. In addition to traditional rocking-chair batteries, PB/PBAs can also be applied in conversion-type batteries. Pang et al. used high-entropy PBAs as a polysulfide immobilizer to suppress the shuttle effect and as a catalyst to facilitate the conversion of polysulfides in lithium-sulfur batteries. Liu et al. prepared highly active M o 2 C / C o nanostructures by using Z n 3 [ C o ( C N ) 6 ] 2 as a precursor and ammonium tetrathiomolybdate through pyrolysis, which provided more catalytic active sites and storage space for the L i 2 O 2 discharge products [100,146]. 5.1.2 Aqueous electrolyte batteries Batteries using aqueous electrolytes offer high safety and environmental friendliness, with limitless potential for large-scale energy storage devices, in which these batteries are primarily based on multivalent metal-ion chemistries. However, the hydrated ions with large radii tend to induce strong electrostatic repulsion with host cathode materials [87,147]. PB/PBAs with a 3D open framework are capable of accommodating multivalent hydrated ions, and the water molecules adsorbed within the PB/PBAs can shield the electrostatic repulsion, thereby indirectly enhancing the stability of the PB/PBAs. For instance, Mantia et al. constructed a novel eco-friendly zinc-ion battery based on a K 0.71 C u [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.72 · 3.7 H 2 O cathode and aqueous Z n S O 4 electrolyte [148]. Xia et al. reported an aqueous magnesium-ion battery matched with N a 1.4 N i 1.3 F e ( C N ) 6 · 5 H 2 O cathode and polyimide anode [149]. Yao et al. employed K 0.02 C u [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 0.66 · 3.7 H 2 O for fast and stable calcium-ion storage [150]. In addition, PB/PBAs have also been demonstrated to be suitable as cathode materials for aqueous non-metallic ion batteries, such as those for storing H+ and NH4 + ions [5,142,151]. The unique structure of PB/PBAs allows for efficient ion insertion and extraction, making them ideal for use in these types of batteries. 5.1.3 Supercapacitor Batteries exhibit high energy density but suffer from insufficient power density, whereas supercapacitors represent an energy storage technology with high power density. Supercapacitors are categorized into electric double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors, based on the energy storage mechanisms of electrostatic ion absorption/desorption and faradaic process, respectively. Carbon materials like porous carbon, graphene, and carbon nanotubes are employed as electrode material in EDLCs, while transition metal oxides and conductive polymers with faradaic reactions are more suitable for pseudocapacitors [152,153]. PB/PBAs and their derivatives, composed of transition metals and featuring hollow structures, have garnered significant attention from researchers for supercapacitors. Yuan et al. prepared C o 3 O 4 - N i O / G F composites as self-supporting electrodes for supercapacitors by modifying the surface of GF with C o ( H 2 O ) 2 [ N i ( C N ) 4 ] followed by calcination, which resulted in significantly improved specific capacitance, rate capability, and cycling stability [154]. Wei et al. prepared hollow CoHCF submicron boxes for sodium-ion hybrid supercapacitors via a cation exchange method [155]. 5.2 Catalysis PB/PBAs are suitable for catalytic applications due to the presence of CN bridges, which connect transition metals with different oxidation states and serve as excellent electronic channels, ensuring efficient electron transfer between the transition metals [156,157]. In addition, PB/PBAs features an open framework, high specific surface area, and numerous active sites, which further enhance their catalytic capabilities [157]. In this section, we introduce the catalytic functions of PB/PBAs and their derivatives in two application fields of electrocatalytic water splitting and degradation of organic pollution compounds. 5.2.1 Electrochemical water splitting Hydrogen energy, an efficient and clean energy option, is regarded as a key component of future clean energy systems. Hydrogen, as an energy carrier, is typically produced through the process of water electrolysis. During water electrolysis, two half-reactions are involved: the hydrogen evolution reaction (Eq. (3)) and the oxygen evolution reaction (Eq. (4)) [158], as detailed below (3) H E R : 2 H + + 2 e - → 2 H 2 (4) O E R : 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - (5) T o t a l r e a c t i o n : 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 2 H 2 During water electrolysis, catalysts such as ruthenium and iridium oxides are required to reduce overpotentials and improve Faradaic efficiency, thereby minimizing energy consumption [159]. However, these expensive catalysts severely limit their large-scale applications. Therefore, low-cost materials including PB/PBAs and their derivatives with high catalytical activity are expected to serve as promising alternatives. In fact, significant progress has already been made in the fields of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) using PB/PBAs and their derivatives. For example, Lou et al. facilitated the reaction between N i 3 [ C o ( C N ) 6 ] 2 · 12 H 2 O and ammonium thiomolybdate under solvothermal conditions to form Ni-Co-MoS2 nanoboxes with enhanced electrocatalytic activity for HER reaction [160]. Yu et al. utilized ionized nitrogen plasma to impact K 2 N i [ F e ( C N ) 6 , forming unconventional CN vacancies that enables highly efficient OER catalysis [30]. 5.2.2 Degradation of organic pollution compound The catalysis degradation of organic pollution compounds directly influences the quality of human life. The catalysis effect of PB/PBAs and their derivatives in this field is primarily based on the activation of hydrogen peroxide (Fenton reaction) and persulfates by transition metal ions [161,162]. These two action mechanism pathways are expressed as follows. Fenton reaction (6) M 2 + + H 2 O 2 → M 3 + + O H · + ( O H ) - (7) M 3 + + H 2 O 2 → M 2 + + H O 2 · + H + Peroxymonosulfate activation reaction (8) H S O 5 - + M 2 + → M 3 + + S O 4 · - + ( O H ) - (9) H S O 5 - + M 3 + → M 2 + + S O 5 · - + H + Many organic pollutants can be degraded by utilizing PB/PBAs-based catalysts to activate the generation of free radicals ( OH and SO4 −). For example, Chen et al. employed a substitution-co-assembly strategy to synthesize binary Ce-Fe Prussian blue analogues for high-efficiency degradation of sulfamethoxazole [163]. Wang et al. prepared Zn-Fe double oxides with superior photo-Fenton removal efficiency of BPA by calcining ( Z n 1 - x F e x ) 3 [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 2 precursor in air, which exhibited excellent performance in the peroxysulfate-based photo-Fenton system and effectively degraded Bisphenol A [164]. 5.3 Adsorption Due to high surface area, strong ion-exchange capacity, and tunable structure, PB/PBAs have been found to effectively capture heavy metal ions (such as Cd, As, Sr, Pb, and Cs). Moreover, adsorbent based on PB/PBAs have been developed with faster adsorption kinetics, contributing significantly to the creation of a harmonious ecological system. The mechanism of heavy metal ion removal by PB/PBAs primarily relies on their unique structural adsorption and ion exchange properties. Zhang et al. synthesized PB tetragonal nanorods via a template-free solvothermal method, achieving maximum adsorption capacities for Cs+ and Sr2+ of 194.26 and 256.62 mg g−1 [165]. Dong et al. synthesized mesoporous K 2 Z n 3 [ F e ( C N ) 6 ] 2 assisted by ionic liquids, and the unique nanostructure imparted an improved Cs+ adsorption capacity (548.7 mg g−1), placing it at the highest level among Cs+ adsorbents [166]. Wang et al. prepared a Cs metal adsorbent with a high specific surface area and good hydrophilicity by anchoring Ni-based PBAs on 3D-reduced graphene aerogel. This composite material showed excellent adsorption performance for Cs, with a maximum adsorption capacity of 204.9 mg g−1 [167]. 5.4 Sensor PB/PBAs possess a highly tunable metal-cyanide framework, along with the advantages of non-toxicity and low cost, making them excellent electron transfer medium. This endows PB/PBAs with significant application value in the field of sensors, where they have been utilized for the detection of substances such as glucose, hydrogen peroxide, and ascorbic acid. For example, Karadas et al. prepared cobalt hexacyanoferrate electrodes via electrochemical deposition under neutral conditions as non-enzymatic glucose sensors, achieving linear detection of glucose in the range of 0.1–8.2 mmol L−1 with a detection limit of 67 μM, sensitivity of 18.69 mA mM−1 cm−2, and a response time of less than 7 s [167,168]. Gorton et al. proposed a semi-empirical model for diffusion-limited current distribution on narrow-wall jet electrodes, validating that Prussian blue exhibits catalytic activity comparable to that of peroxidase enzymes [168,169]. Xu et al. developed a capacitive sensor for ultra-low concentration ammonia detection using Cu-Fe PBAs, which adsorbed approximately 10 ppm of ammonia at 1 atm, with an adsorption efficiency of 2.2 mmol g−1 as measured by the QCM frequency response [170]. 5.5 Electromagnetic wave absorption With the development of wireless technology, the widespread generation of electromagnetic waves has posed a serious threat to the human living environment. PB/PBAs derivatives, which belong to metal–organic frameworks, have emerged as an important solution to electromagnetic pollution. PBAs with high specific surface area, high porosity, and tunable metal ions, when subjected to high-temperature pyrolysis to transform into nanoscale materials, can still maintain their unique porous structure, making them a promising candidate for high-performance microwave absorption materials. Ji et al. proposed carbon-based composites with advantages such as lightweight, ultrathin, strong microwave attenuation capability, and wide effective absorption bandwidth by thermally treating CoFe-PBAs [55]. Yao et al. in situ synthesized carbon nanotubes on the surface of Co-based PBA via pyrolysis to form a cubic porous PBAs derivative (CoCN@CNT), with the resulting CoCN@CNT achieving coverage of the entire Ku-band and part of the X-band at a 20% filling ratio [169–171]. Zhong et al. prepared a multi-component nanocomposite with strong adsorption capacity and broad absorption bandwidth for electromagnetic wave absorption through in situ pyrolysis and hydrothermal synthesis of Co-Ni PBAs [172]. In a word, this section presents some representative research works on PB/PBAs in various fields, highlighting the irreplaceable position of PB/PBAs in the scientific domain. Furthermore, the details of the synthesis factors for PB/PBAs via the co-precipitation method suggest that there are still many shortcomings in the current research on PB/PBAs (Table 1 ). (1) Some researchers completely ignore the reaction rate during the synthesis of PB/PBAs, resulting in crystals with low crystallinity and poor stability. This severely impacts the performance of PB/PBAs in different fields. For instance, when low-crystallinity PB/PBAs are used as energy storage materials, they may undergo significant phase transitions and structural collapse during the charge and discharge processes, leading to battery failure. Similarly, when low-crystallinity PB/PBAs are employed as catalysts, the uneven distribution of active sites within the structure severely reduces the catalytic efficiency. (2) Others have recognized the importance of controlling the synthesis factors to limit the reaction rate. However, they lack an understanding of the mechanisms and synergistic effects of various synthesis factors, making it difficult for them to fully consider which factors need to be adjusted when synthesizing PBAs with high crystallinity. (3) Very few researchers have been able to precisely control the synthesis factors to fabricate PB/PBAs suitable for different applications. For example, when PB/PBAs are used as energy storage materials, a higher content of alkali metal ions in the crystal structure is desirable, which can be regulated through the reactant concentration and reaction atmosphere. In some biomedical fields, extremely small-sized PB/PBAs nanoparticles are required, which can be finely tuned through factors such as chelating agents, reaction temperature, and aging time—yet these aspects are often overlooked. Therefore, it is urged that researchers, while pursuing methods for modifying PB/ss, also focus on the importance of synthesizing PB/PBAs with high quality. 6 Summary 6.1 Conclusions In summary, this review provides a brief overview of the development of PB/PBAs and focuses on the synthesis methods, crystal structures, precise fabrication, and application fields of PB/PBAs. The specific content is as follows. (I) For the synthesis methods of PB/PBAs, different methods can be selected based on specific requirement, such as productivity, crystallinity, and cost. It is noteworthy that, although the co-precipitation process tends to result in relatively lower crystallinity compared to other synthesis methods, its preeminent advantages in large-scale production, cost, and safety make it occupy an irreplaceable position. Therefore, improving the crystallinity of the co-precipitation method will greatly promote the development and practical applications of PB/PBAs-based materials. (II) The composition of PB/PBAs, including alkali metals, transition metals coordinated with carbon, transition metals coordinated with nitrogen, structural water, and structural vacancies, determines the physicochemical properties of different types of PBAs. Understanding this concept allows for a clearer comprehension of the principles and mechanisms underlying the diverse applications of PBAs across multiple fields. (III) Considering the synthesis methods for different PB/PBAs, the optimized co-precipitation method will be the preferred approach. By controlling synthesis factors such as chelating agents and reaction temperature to slow down the reaction rate between cyanide and transition metal ions, the crystallinity of PB/PBAs nanoparticles can be significantly improved. Additionally, adjusting factors like reactant concentration can help control particle size, which is essential for the precise fabrication of PBAs. It is important to note that there is a synergistic mechanism between different synthesis factors. Simply choosing a chelating agent and controlling the reaction temperature does not guarantee that all PBAs will exhibit low-defect structures. (IV) To date, PB/PBAs and their derivatives have been widely applied in various fields, highlighting the significant role of PB/PBAs in scientific research. Therefore, synthesizing PB/PBAs with strong structural stability and high crystallinity not only advances the development of PB/PBAs themselves but also holds the potential to break through the current performance limits in various fields. This further underscores the urgency of regulating specific synthesis factors when synthesizing different PB/PBAs. 6.2 Perspectives Despite the long history of PB and the diverse types of PBAs, which have gained widespread attention across various fields due to their unique framework structures and rich compositional elements, the relationship between the physicochemical properties, synthesis methods, and crystal structures of PB/PBAs has not triggered sufficient importance in the pursuit of superior device performance. Furthermore, due to the awareness of the harm caused by defects and production costs, numerous studies have been reported on optimizing the co-precipitation method to produce high-crystallinity PB/PBAs. However, these studies typically focus on just one or two synthesis factors, overlooking the synergistic effects between different factors and the unique characteristics of synthesizing different PBAs. This severely confuses researchers on how to control synthesis parameters to produce high-crystallinity PB/PBAs. Based on the aforementioned content, we provide a comprehensive description from composition to applications, while offering a solid theoretical foundation for researchers to fabricate the required PBAs precisely. After clearly understanding the mechanisms by which different synthesis factors contribute to the preparation of high-crystallinity PB/PBAs, we propose the development of customized synthesis strategies for PB/PBAs tailored to meet diverse application requirements. Specifically, due to the differences in the ionic radii and chelating ability of various transition metal ions in the synthesis materials, careful attention should be paid to selecting appropriate chelating agents, reaction temperatures, and other synthesis factors, particularly when synthesizing multi-component PBAs. Additionally, for PB/PBAs used in different fields, it is crucial to control the appropriate particle size, alkali metal content, and transition metal oxidation state content. This will help PB/PBAs render optimal performance, facilitating their scientific research and scalable practical application. Zhong, Nano Res. 15 (2022) 6761–6771 Yicheng Tan is a Ph.D. candidate in the College of Physics, Jilin University. His research focuses on electrochemical energy storage based on Prussian blue and Prussian blue analogue nanomaterials. Duo Chen is an assistant professor at the College of Material Science and Technology, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China. He received his Ph.D. in applied physics from Jilin University in 2021. His research focuses on nanomaterials and their applications in electrochemical energy storage. Laifa Shen is a professor and Associate Dean of the College of Material Science and Technology, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA), China. He received his Ph.D. in material physics and chemistry from NUAA in 2014. He worked at the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research as a Staff Scientist from 2015 to 2019. His research focuses on fast-charging battery/capacitive materials and devices. Wei Han joined the College of Physics, Jilin University as a professor in 2001. His current research focuses on the synthesis of nanomaterials and their potential applications in energy storage devices and nuclear waste water purification.

coredata.dc:description: Prussian blue/Prussian blue analogues (PB/PBAs) are widely used in electrochemistry and materials science fields, such as electrochemical energy storage, catalysis, water purification, and electromagnetic wave absorption, owing to their 3D open-framework structure, tunable composition, and large specific surface area. However, the co-precipitation method, which is most suitable for large-scale production of PB/PBAs, often leads to the formation of numerous crystal defects and severe lattice distortion, which significantly affects the structural stability of PB/PBAs. To obtain high-crystallinity PB/PBAs with targeted properties, precise synthesis considering various detailed conditions is especially needed. Herein, this review comprehensively summarizes the fundamental structure composition, key factors in synthesis, and applications in the electrochemistry of PB/PBAs. Unlike previous reports, this review elucidates the relationship between the physicochemical properties of PB/PBAs and their structural composition, with a particular focus on revealing the mechanisms and significance of specific preparation methods during the synthesis process, including reactant concentration, chelating agent, aging, atmosphere, temperature, and drying conditions, for achieving the precise fabrication of PB/PBAs nanomaterials. As PB/PBAs gradually become materials for multidimensional applications, we urge greater attention to the unique properties of PB/PBAs that are sustained by high crystallinity and stable crystal structures. This will effectively ensure the maximization of their advantages in practical applications.
